author: Staff Reporter
text:
A two-day national seminar organised by Annammal College of Education, Thoothukudi, on “Promoting human rights culture in higher education institutions” commenced here on Tuesday.

Delivering the keynote address, Henry Tiphagne, Executive Director of People’s Watch, a human rights organisation in Madurai, stressed the need for including human rights education as part of curriculum. Despite advocating the need for human rights education in syllabus, universities were reluctant to include it. Calling it unfortunate, he said nevertheless, teachers should mould students with a sense of social equality in their minds to end caste discrimination. He said human rights literacy was not widespread and its value was largely unknown to people.

Beula Shekar, Department of Victimology, Manonmaniam Sundaranar University, and B. Radha, Department of Communication, MSU, also spoke.

Earlier, Mr. Tiphagne released a book, ‘Promoting Human Rights Culture in Higher Education Institutions,’ and Mr. Ganesan received the first copy. . A. Joycilin Shermila, Principal, welcomed the gathering.
title: “Include human rights in curriculum”
